Comment: The Leafs worst mistake would be to chase "help me now" players and give up potential to get it.  Simply, they are not yet at that stage.  This is the year to see how far they can go with the current players.  Besides being a learning experience (make the playoffs or not), the experience will be a true gauge of what they need and where they need it.  Defence is an obvious example but it is not the only one.

Use this opportunity to accurately assess the next stage of their development rather than think that this core group of players with strategic additions can make a deep run.  They need to keep the long range mission front and centre (competitive team every year knowing in October that they will make the playoffs).

Giving up potential at this stage will be a signal that Shanahan has lost his influence (in my view).

Comment: https://www.cms.gov/CCIIO/Resources/Forms-Reports-and-Other-Resources/Downloads/Rate-Review-Annual-Report_508.pdf

After the enactment of the Affordable Care Act, average rate increases in the individual market
moderated to 7.0 percent in 2011 and 7.1 percent in 2012. The average rate increase was 10.3
percent in 2013, but would have been 8.7 percent if the high increases in one outlier state were
excluded. This report shows that rate increases have remained moderate since 2013. The
average rate increase in the individual market was 2.4 percent in 2014 and 6.9 percent in 2015.
In the small group market, the average annual rates of increase were 6.1 percent in 2011, 4.7
percent in 2012 and 7.1 percent in 2013.3 Small group rate increases have also remained
moderate since 2013. In the small group market, the average rate increase was 3.6 percent in
2014 and 4.3 percent in 2015.

Comment: I wonder if Feinstein's use of "dogma" was actually strategic. I imagine she's aware that, for many, it's an oppressive-sounding words that elicits an involuntarily negative response. It definitely sounds less positive (and less liberal) than "social doctrine" or "moral teaching" or a host of other terms she could've used that would've been more accurate.

If all this leads to a serious discussion about what it means to practice one's faith in the public arena, I'd be all for it. Bring it on. I'd love for the door to be opened to a robust discussion about whether one can be a conscientious, pro-life Catholic and still be opposed to legislative and judicial restraints on personal choice. For the record, I believe one can.

But I don't think that's what Feinstein was doing. I think this was an intentional shot across the bow of Catholicism. And she deserves to be called on it.

Comment: Another note on Angela Merkel and her Christian Democratic Party. She is not a neo-liberal in the American sense. Christian Democrats have their own trade union movement in much of Europe, and in Germany, the Christian Democrats have been in coalition with the Social Democrats for 2 of her 3 terms in office. That union may be forced by political necessity, but it remains popular in Germany, with the CDP and SDP together being the preference of 55 percnt of German voters. 

The liberal party of Germany are the Free Democrats, who were in coalition with the Christian Democrats til they fell below the 5 percent threshold for Bundestag representation in the last german election. 

The Christian Democratic Party does not sit with the British Conservatives or other Thatcherite neo classical liberal groups in the European Parliament. 

President Obama and his Wall Street appointees and soon-to-be-payers-of-speech-fees may want to think Angela Merkel is neo liberal, but its not the situation.

Comment: Coming back to your earlier comment about profiteering. The "once off" investments get discounted over their lifetime (i.e. a portion of the cost gets charged to each item over the lifetime of the investment), like roads and hospitals and other item should. You extend their lifetime by maintaining them. That is another cost. You pay for the electricity for all those lights and air conditioners and refrigerators. You pay for the salaries of your staff. You allow for some theft. You allow for waste (although I think that the suppliers carry that to an extent). You rent the space for your store (if it is in a shopping centre). All these items add up. Even after having squeezed every drop of blood out of every suppliers and every farmer they still make only 2% profit. How did they profiteer during the drought? Did they not drop prices below cost?

Comment: That's a bit of a distortion though. I as a taxpayer already help fund Borough Parks and Recreation maintenance as a property owner, same as everyone else. Therefore, I am already in essence paying to use the park. By licensing a pet, I am paying for the right to keep a pet and take the pet into public spaces. Therefore, I have already paid twice for that privilege, and I am expected as a result to keep my pet properly restrained and clean up after it.

A trapper has the same rights to use public space as a taxpayer, however, they are actually taking an additional natural resource from the space. They are not merely using the space and it's trails, but they are actually acquiring a resource and then removing that resource from the space. That alone is a solid reason to require an additional fee such as a license. I agree your fees go to conservation, but that is offsetting the impact you are having. If I clean up after myself and my pet, then my impact is negligible if any exists.

Comment: His past history is admissible but there are guidelines the judge will use of what can be admissible. Generally, prosecutors can't use evidence of prior convictions to prove a defendant’s guilt or tendency to commit crimes, but they can sometimes use them to question the truthfulness or credibility of the defendant’s testimony.

Consider the following example, which shows how judges determine whether to admit prior convictions of testifying defendants:
A defendant is charged with murder and has a prior conviction for passing bad checks. Because the prior conviction involves a crime of dishonesty, the judge will probably allow the prosecutor to question the defendant about it.

Comment: As I see it sports programs are all facing  a similar fate: extinction. It not just here in Alaska but across the country.  Injuries of athletes leads to millions of dollars in settlements. Athletic fields, stadiums and arenas cost multi-millions to maintain.  While most schools are facing some level of budget reductions: academics v athletics.   

No doubt there are a few athletic events that make money for the school. Most of these activities do not come close to breaking even  when travel cost, facilities and coaches salaries are all factored into the numbers.  All these programs came to be in  a slowly increasing variety of events. Look back 50 years and identify the number of sports on a typical college/university campus.  You will find only  a few events shown in years books. 

The largest of the universities, with large alumni and corporate sponsors,  will be the ones to hold on the longest. The rest, state funded for the most part, athletics will fade away due to cost.

Comment: On reading Ms. Perlow's treatise, I feel sick to my stomach at its self serving nature.  I have some questions:
1.  Who determines the level and nature of charges, i.e. felony, measure 11, etc.?
2. Who determines how many charges will be leveled as a result of a single incident, i.e. ten felonies for stealing ten loaves of bread?
3. The grand jury is supposed to ensure that prosecutor's are correct in their charges.  How many times, as a percentage, does the grand jury refuse to follow the prosecutor's recommendation?
4. Who controls presentation of facts to the grand jury?
5. Who is in control of plea bargains, i.e. determines the original charges and determines the reduced charges available for a guilty plea (regardless of true guilt or innocence)?
6. Are judges allowed to adjust sentences if it is clear to him/her that the prosecutor has overcharged?
7. In any crowd, how many people typically accept the word of authority?  Non-unanimous juries allow nearly universal convictions.

Comment: Years ago I read an article, which proposed that making claims about empathy is a kind of presumption.(Unfortunately I can't remember the author.  Austin Clarke perhaps? The article was in this paper in the Facts & Arguments section when it was still meant to be a kind of philosophical Op Ed section with articles by various writers, academics and other pundits instead of the general public writing in about personal life issues. )  

I think that article - and this one in a less erudite way - made a good point.  To say you empathize implies that you get where the other person is coming from, you 'feel their pain'.  Come now, do you really?  It is far more accurate to say that you are sympathetic to the other, that you have compassion for their plight.  Maybe you'll even stir yourself to help out.  But to assume someone's pain without actually feeling it can be offensive.

Comment: Not all tribes have "opted" for that, at least, tribes in the lower 48, that I know of. 
The tribe in Ketchikan, "opted" for the tribe to run the clinic and provide medical and dental services about 20 yrs ago under contract.
Previously it had been under IHS, then administered by SERACH, now KIC.
If you need to be hospitalized or see a specialist you go to Anchorage or Sitka.
If I go South on vacation and get sick, I can received services from IHS if there is one where I am at.
The tribe gets a certain amount money used to operate the medical and dental clinic. It is required to provide basic services to any Am.Indian or Ak. Native, not just tribal members.
There is "other" money that provides certain services only for tribal members. 
The tribal clinic bills Medicare, Medicaid, VA, or private insurance, that money goes into unrestricted account for tribal use. 
Under OBAMA Care, everyone  was "asked" to sign up for insurance the tribe paid for but only to be used at the tribal clinic

Comment: Peak Oil is not a farce.  Rather, it is represented by the point in time when the (a) upward trend over time of global demand for oil intersects with the (b) downward trend of global oil production at a market price that consumers are prepared to pay.

Clearly, paragraph (b) above is both difficult to calculate with any exactness and shifts as alternative energy sources become more generally available at reduced cost and as the cost of extraction of oil (both from conventional and unconventional sources) increases.

Arguably, the intersection of these two trends will occur on a sustained basis within the next decade or two.

Comment: Here's how you balance the budget, quick, simple and clean.

Cut funding to megaprojects like the gas line, the Port MacKenzie rail line, Knik bridge, etc.
Cut the Legislatures per diem, etc down to the same rate as the rest of state workers. Eliminate travel unless it's approved by say the Governor. Move the legislature to using State fleet vehicles and housing rather than per diem and moving POVs in Juneau.
Consolidate operations in several areas to reduce duplicate work within departments and the state government as a whole.
Repeal SB21 oil tax breaks
Reduce subsidies to UA system, begin converting UA to an endowment operated school system.
Implement a state income tax at a low rate and "buy out" Alaskans from the PFD (buy out of say, $10-$15k per eligible individual who has received a dividend at least the last 5-7 years) and end future dividend payments entirely. Restructure the PFD so all earnings go towards the state budget in lean times or improving principal in wealthy times

Comment: About a year ago the Financial Times online newspaper published a very good interactive model of global warming. You could play with any country's emissions (just a click of the mouse) to see what the effect would be on global warming. I played with Canada's inputs but no matter what values I chose it made no difference to global warming. In fact the only way I could change the bottom line in terms of global warming was by playing with inputs from USA, China, EU, India and Russia. If you played with the rest of the developing world (excluding China) you could also change the situation to some extent.

Given the above I would say that Canada should do no more than what everyone else is doing to lower emissions. There's no point sabotaging our economy by doing more than everyone else to reduce emissions if it makes no difference to global warming.

Comment: It appears to be settled in the Catholic theology of orders that Holy Orders consists of deacon, priest, and bishop. "§3. Those who are constituted in the order of episcopate or presbyterate receive the office and faculty of acting in the person of Christ the Head, while deacons receive the power to serve the people of God in the diaconia of liturgy, word and charity."

Comment: "This project" if it had gone ahead, would have involved years of construction before it started operating, and decades of operating life. In order to determine whether or not the project is economically viable, you would need to accurately forecast market conditions from the time the project began operation to the end of its operating life. 

IF market conditions remain unchanged for the next few decades, you would be correct that "the project was a loser to begin with". However, the one sure thing we know about markets is that they DON'T STAY THE SAME for any long period. Whether or not a LNG plant on which construction begins today will make a profit in the long term is a matter of guesswork.

Comment: Your point is deserving of more attention.  

We have our provincial (and municipal) politicians publicly, with their sad concerned faces, declaring that they are worried over the lack of housing affordability. Working families are leaving, and many have high debt levels.

Yet the BC Liberals have a law that states that a landlord can apply to have rents for existing tenants increased to match competitors rents.  So if other apartment buildings in the neighbourhood  have been able to reno-vict their tenants, or through the process of short term leases rents have been jacked, or turn-over and new builds are commanding higher rent,  then  those high rents can apply to other existing tenants, of any comparable unit,  in the area.

And the new higher rents do not have to be implemented gradually, tenants can see an instant 50% increase. 

So ask yourself why the BC Liberals, so caring and compassionate about working families, have not modified this law into something more reasonable.

Comment: I am afraid I do not agree with your definition of intolerance.  Disagreement with a viewpoint does not constitute intolerance.

Denying basic rights because you disagree with a viewpoint does.

The federal government showed intolerance toward homosexuals during the sixties sweep, for example.  Many show intolerance toward Muslims when they say they should not be granted asylum based on their faith.

I dispute that humans need a moral law giver, though.  An educated and compassionate person should be able to make these decisions for him/herself.  There are those that choose to delegate that responsibility to another, be it a religious authority, philosopher, or other perceived leader.  Speaking for myself, I prefer to apply critical thought to moral dilemmas and apply my own judgment.  Either approach is valid and is entirely dependent upon the individual.  But an outside moral authority is not necessary for a person to behave in a dignified and respectful fashion.

Comment: All of the things you mention are included in the CPI. You don't know what you are talking about. The initial core inflation measure used by the Bank of Canada as an operational guide, CPIXFET, excluded food, energy and changes in indirect taxes. But it was replaced by CPIX in May 2001, which doesn't exclude most food categories, nor does it exclude electricity. Due to the incompetence of Finance Minister Bill Morneau and Governor Poloz it has in turn been replaced by three other measures, none of which exclude all food and energy. They all exclude changes in indirect taxes, as they should.

Comment: 'I had always thought of mathematics as that most scientific of scientific subjects.' 
Science describes the empirical disciplines. Technically, maths is not empirical because it's abstract, pure theory, like philosophy and theology. It's a paradox because maths is the language, or theoretical tool, scientists used to define, test and prove their observations of the physical world and convert it into a model. Some disciplines, eg natural sciences, may be understood without maths, but it's essential for the physical sciences, esp physics and astronomy.

Geez, in the presence of greatness and I asked for directions to a cigarette machine.

Comment: This report jumps to a pre-ordained conclusion.  Why was there no assessment of Ontario's cost structures if the hyothesis is that electricity costs alone caused these job losses?  The data is readily available so why was it not used?

Take 2014, a year smack dab in the middle of this period.  KPMG released a 2014 study that measures the combined impact of 26 key cost components that vary by location, over a 10-year analysis horizon starting in 2014. 

http://www.competitivealternatives.com/highlights/cities3.aspx
 
Looking at Northeast  US versus Canada the report finds Quebec City is the lowest cost metropolitan area to do business, followed by Niagara region (yes in Ontario), Montreal and then Sudbury (Yes in Ontario). Within Canada Toronto is a lower cost centre than either Edmonton or Vancouver.

Furthermore, if there was all this disasterous job loss then why are Ontario's emigration rates so low (just under  0.023%).

Comment: Yes, a comprehensive review of Canada's tax system, objectives, laws and regulations is needed.  There has not been such a full and thorough review since Diefenbaker initiated a royal commission on tax reform headed by Ken Carter in 1962.

Whether by all-party select standing committee or a royal commission of outside experts with full public hearings and the necessary research resources to do the job, it is a job that needs doing.

My preference for a royal commission is because it should ensure less partisan politics and more relevant expertise and in any case the royal commission's report would then be reviewed by a parliamentary committee and its recommendations further debated and voted on in parliament before any changes are made.

It will take longer and cost more but the issues involved justify this ultimate approach IMO.

But I certainly agree that a serious and comprehensive review of our tax system rather than a hurried patch-work politically motivated approach is past due.

Comment: Think about it: Not a single US intelligence agency, including the domestic services, is suggesting that the outcome of the election was swayed. So why would an outgoing president make such a huge deal out of this?

A president is sworn to uphold his country's constitution. He should do everything he can to uphold its  citizen's trust in their electoral system. He must put his country's interests ahead of any personal or political feelings he has for an incoming administration. By all means he should warn the incoming president about any threats to the country, but privately. 

Using an allegation to erode your citizens' faith in the democratic system is behavior unbecoming of a president. Trump was properly criticized for doing so as a presidential candidate. However, using an allegation for no other purpose than to publicly discredit an incoming administration is politics at its ugliest.  It remains to be seen if Trump will go that low.

A similar question came up years ago in Fairfax County Va, when a court judge who carried a firearm when on the bench, if it was legal if he stopped at a store while traveling to and from work. Comment: That was not my case. The first aboriginals we met when we arrived in Canada were a family of Inuits that had fled the North to escape abuse. It was shocking to see the suffering they had endured. 

In these last few years, my interactions with aboriginals have been as a landlord. Over the past six years I have had say 7 or 8 different aboriginal families as tenants. The good ones were those that paid the rent, didn't damage the place, and still wanted to cut their lease short after just a few months. The other half thrashed the place, and stopped paying rent altogether under a huge variety of excuses. Besides these people, I have had tenants from Canada, Mexico, Australia, France, Pakistan, India, Saudi Arabia, Kenia, Nigeria, Cameroon, and I'm probably forgetting a couple places. No issues with any of them.

Comment: I suggest the following interim alternative to universal health care that may address concerns on both sides of the health care debate:

1. Allow any person or family  who has been denied health care coverage due to a pre-existing condition the option to purchase Medicare coverage.  Payments would be determined via a combination of annual pre-tax income and age.  

2. Change Medicare to a different organizational structure focused on continuously driving down costs and  improving quality of care, similar to a for-profit business in a competitive environment, by taking advantage of economies of scale from the increased number of Medicare enrollees and by adopting global best practices from countries with lower universal health care costs.

3. Medicare funding deficits under this plan for any year would be paid in the following year via an incremental additional flat tax of  X% of the deficit applied to all US health care premiums plus 100-X % on all reported pre-tax  income.

Comment: There are key issues that Hawai'i can learn (good & bad) from the practices & concerns that California & and Californians have had to deal with- from coastal erosion & unchecked development to water conservation (or lack thereof) to employment, shadow economies (cash-based) to the challenges of the land being very attractive to investors & speculators (both foreign & domestic).  

Environmental concerns for the Islands are greater as we are geographically isolated and we all (should) care about native species and the unanticipated consequences associated with invasive / foreign species (flora & fauna).  Our coastal reefs continue to be at risk from both higher temps as well as studies that indicate that oxybenzone in sunscreens is killing the juvenile coral.  

Water rights & distribution was for fighting in CA and still is, even with a few years of ample rainfall.  

Transportation is a headache for any large population base- those Red Cars were visionary but so against Big Auto.

Comment: Ultimately, IMHO, yes. Just as Yahweh remained utterly faithful to Israel, despite her considerable lapses, so to I believe the Spirit will remain faithful to her holy people of God; and within that community, I accept the sacrament of orders as selecting the episcopal college for the charism of teaching.

That said, I think we have to distinguish three magisteria: bishops as a college, theologians as a college, and the people as a whole. Presently the three are obviously not in sync, and my money is on the bishops as the magisterium that our future will identify as having been in error about the big ticket items (women priests, married clergy, sexual ethics) that rile Catholics in western countries. 

It is critically important, IMHO, to know about the iconoclast controversy in this regard. Back then, at one point the majority of bishops in council were on what history established to have been the wrong side. The people disagreed, for the most part, and were proved correct.

Comment: The times I've delayed putting studded tires on my car until late November have resulted in my car slithering out of control on downhills coming into stop lights when the temperature is 32 degrees after a freezing rain. The light goes yellow and I don't have enough time to stop before the light goes red. In my experience the studs make the difference between stopping the car safely and ending up in the ditch or rear ending another car. Yes we should drive slowly enough that we can stop safely and we should give the car ahead of us plenty of room, but we make mistakes. Some intersections are slicker than others. Sometimes there is low visibility and the car in front stops or slows suddenly. I'm interested in Blizzaks and would like to see results for coming downhill into icy intersections at 32 degrees. I'm unsure if the higher taxes are cost effective. Discouraging stud usage might raise the number of accidents for increased medical costs and car repair costs.

Comment: Historic Detail — The 6% "PERS pickup" happened in 1979.  Many state employee bargaining contracts had a Cost-of-Living index on them.  But in 1979, the inflation rate was 18%.  To save the state money, the employees agreed to having the public employer "pick up" the 6% contribution (to match the previous 6% employer share) and thereby SAVE the state 12% of a Cost of Living adjustment.  Now of course, critics say employees "aren't even paying for their own retirement."  What was a GIFT to the State of Oregon, taking 6% instead of the contracted 18% that year, is now seen as "cheating."  
   It really comes down to having a retirement plan still in place when most big businesses have been able to "get rid" of those things for their workers so as to get more money for the "Golden Parachutes" for top management.
    I know one employee of a large local firm who was fired the week before he was to retire, after 45 years with the company.  Should THAT be "reformed"?

Comment: I think that the battery energy density problem that limits range and rapid reenergizing will be a limitation that even batteries that are just in the research phase will not overcome. Batteries with fuel cells are in the development and deployment phase so they are a much closer technology than pure electric. Plug in gas hybrids significantly reduce pollution and fossil fuel consumption for people in the city with shorter trips so more charging stations make sense in the city.
Encouraging PV covered parking lots will help reduce local heating as well as produce renewable power locally. Ground sourced heat pumps should be considered for new and replacement for commercial buildings. Using electric tools like mowers and saws is a good idea.
I always want to see things that reduce pollution and improve the environment, but pure battery powered cars are one of those things like corn based ethanol that is an oversell and gives the environmental movement a bad name.

Comment: Unlike cigarettes, the connection you've made between preservatives and cancer is entirely unproven. As for "chemicals" being bad, you're going to be very disappointed when you find out that water is in fact H2O, a chemical compound.

Diet affects cancer risk to some extent, but by how much? It's hotly debated. Even if you reduce the contribution of diet to a minimum, the fact is that the longer humans live, the more chance we'll eventually succumb to random, spontaneous cancer. Entropy always wins.

Gas mileage has improved because technology made it possible to reduce fuel consumption without significantly hurting engine performance. The same cannot be said for food. Food generally can't be made calorie-lighter without impacting the flavour or portion size.

And a Big Mac is only 520 calories.

Comment: I like this plan.

People who understand economics will like this plan. Smart people.

Others? Not so much.

We lost a lot of ground under the Harper regime. Remember, Liberals left huge double surpluses for Mr Harper. He proceeded immediately to destroy both and put Canada through two recessions.

Meanwhile, he cut taxes during an expansionary cycle so that all the benefits were subsumed into inflation. Not smart. Then we had nothing left to fight the recession with except deficits. Way to go, Mr "Pro-Cyclical" Harper.

We're not out of the woods yet, and the time is ripe for Keynesian stimulus. Money targeted at people who spend the money they get. In five years we can replace Keynes with Hayek, but for now this is the way to go.

This is the way to rebuild our economy. The Liberals are right on track, doing what they were elected to do.

Go ahead and criticize them if you want, but they are doing the right thing at the right time. They have my support and gratitude.

Comment: At seventy two I feel very fortunate to be in the shape I am in. I believe it's because I'm pretty active, eat right for the most part and I'm sure my genetics/DNA have a vital role in it as well. I can't control that but why should I? My mother at 87 is a bit bent over from an accidental fall years ago but has no other issues. Mentally and physically pretty sharp and able to be independent for the most part with ADLS etc. Her husband takes good care of her and loves her and she is reciprocal, so I'm tickled. Obviously, I do thank the good Lord for it as well, yes!
Now back to me. I'm acutely aware of the fact that things in life are relative. When we play Pickleball for example I notice a variety of people in varying age categories. Most of them have had knee and back as well as other issues. I feel bad for them but try not to show it. I have my share of stiff painful back issues from a lack of stretching every morning and that'll change soon, it must.
Relativity, it's fun!

Comment: Yes, Elise, you're absolutely correct;  bring back the neighborhood porch concept.  I grew up in a small community in the outskirts of the town area.  Neighbors didn't live close enough to be able to sit on their porches and visit.   But that didn't deter neighbors from getting to know who their neighbors were, and yes, we had our fair share of snitches too.  There was one house in the neighborhood where an elderly woman lived.  She had a short stairway leading up to her back porch.  On a regular basis, she kept her backdoor open and the best thing coming from her back door was the aroma of fresh baked bread and the smell of Folgers Coffee.  I love the aroma and have never forgotten the magic that it bestowed on me and my siblings.  I tried many times to replicate that same aroma but to no avail.  Nothing smells quite like the aroma of grannies backdoor kitchen.  We've lost the magic and security of knowing who our neighbors are, and sadly we oftentimes lose the sense of community.

Comment: A worthy goal, but one I feel is doomed to failure. 

Here are my thoughts. Civil discourse is a rather rare thing to find in America. It's not for lack of a comment system. Facebook, Disqus, and even /. offer ways to recommend people and rate their posts. There's not much different here.  It's because we hate each other with a passion. Right hates Left. Bronco fans hate Patriot Fans. Linux Fans hate Windows Fans. Pepsi drinkers hate Coke drinkers. Ford drivers hate Chevy Drivers. And of course, vice versa. On everything. No commenting systems will fix that. 

But I'm willing to give Civil a try. I like the reactions. Sometimes, you just want to post a 'your idea is bad, and I totally disagree with it', in a single click. Reactions cover that and then some. 

However, this early on, I see one problem in the comment system. Seriously, it's 2017, and we have a character post limit?! Get with the program, and get rid of the character limit!

It really comes down to how important is it to have $X available on a specific date?

Comment: The notion that buying spin-offs is a value play is false.  Value investing requires an understanding of the underpinnings of the business, including management.  This is patently impossible in this scenario.

Spin-offs are capital market imbalances that can have edge for investors set up to buy them.  They fall in the same category as shorting firms that split their stocks, participating in large block trades to change ownership structures (think Nissan-Renault) and a handful  of others.

A far better approach is to view markets in a 3 dimensional way:
 1.) the Chicago price, that is fair value;
 2.) the supply and demand factors, who are the owners, sellers, buyers, what has changed (the above falls in this category); and 
3.) The price statistics. Looking at where prices trade over time relative to fair value.  If a stock is always cheap, it is a value trap.

Investing is much more complex than you suggest and the real story of value is much more nuanced and inaccessible to retail.

Comment: InOregon,       A lot  of truth here with your words-- back when I was young we weren't taught actual history, it was all about  the "Winning  of the West".           No thought was given to what happened to the Indians, nor why we were virtually an all white state.   The "bad part" was erased. Our Centennial in 1959 was all about glorifying our  Pioneer history, little self-reflection on what our history had actually been.  By our Sesquicentennial in 2009 we were beginning to open a bit to review our actual history.  However, most folks weren't really involved.  Only a few folks could have told you who Mathew Deady or Joe Lane were, or known about the Exclusion Act.  

Now, thanks to the Black Lives Matter movement and the support of President Schill, we have thousands of Oregonians reading, learning, and talking about our history, both good and bad.  We'll achieve a balanced history and we'll come out of this experience a stronger and better society.

Comment: Everybody knows the Canadian way is that Canadians with enough disposable money buy no-wait surgery in the USA, while everybody else stays here and languishes on waiting lists.

This Canadian says let's ditch the everybody-should-be-equally-poor mentality regarding health care. The current "Canadian way" is no good.

Comment: Trumps musings may well be legit, but then again, they may only be negotiating bluster.  There are many in the US who say he cannot cancel NAFTA without agreement from congress, which will be very difficult if not impossible to achieve.   On NAFTA, we are protected by the clause that says if it's cancelled then the FTA comes back.  The FTA was essentially the same as NAFTA.  This gives Canada some talk back power at the negotiating table, and allows the negotiators to walk away if they don't like America's demands.  On softwood lumber...Canada has fought this case many times in many arenas and has won every time.  We can't reciprocate with duties of our own on anything other than lumber (US lumber isn't imported into Canada in any great amount.) because the US will then have a good case under NAFTA.

Comment: Where did you learn Roman history?  At Oral Roberts U?  It is not true that "most of the emperors were populists".  The so-called "mob" had decisive political importance in Roman politics only, periodically, from the late second to the late first centuries BC.  After Augustus (who needed neither soldiers nor a mob to maintain his control), the emperors relied heavily on the Praetorians--not "the mob"--to uphold their power.  The Roman street intervened only once, that I can recall, in the first century AD--in 69, the Year of the Four Emperors, Galba made an abortive attempt to arouse the people in his favor.  After Vespasian assumed the purple, the emperors relied solely on the Praetorians and the legions to maintain themselves in power--which meant they could unmake an emperor and make a new one.  When the legions revolted and marched on Rome, sometimes the mob dragged him out and killed him first.  But the people, as such, had no power.

Comment: Lots of organizations help those who are down and out, including Christian and entirely secular organizations. It can get blurry whether or not some of these organizations help people in order to be in a position to proselytize to those down on their luck or if they do it strictly out of a charitable impulse. 
A different approach to charity is that of the Islamic faith called Zakat--the third pillar of Islam. Zakat consists of the compulsory giving of a set proportion of one's wealth to charity and is considered a type of worship and of self-purification. Freeing oneself from the love of possessions and greed, from the love of money and from love of oneself are some of the major goals of this ritual giving. What's interesting about this approach is the focus on how giving edifies the giver rather than the receiver. Sometimes it seems like the Christian approach has more to do with providing social status to the giver. In Zakat, the donations are frequently private or anonymous.

Comment: You mean cold, hard data similar to you "seeing more" Flatiron Flyers?

I don't have any iron-clad, indisputable data like that, but why wouldn't you see more Flatiron Flyers? The 86x route was cancelled (like the 82x and 108x before it), the AB no longer runs between Broomfield and I-25 and the L no longer stops between Broomfield and Denver. The express bus service on U.S. 36 was and still is the best service RTD offers, and it got better when CDOT extended the HOV lanes. But the Flatiron Flyer is a re-branding, not a service improvement.

What I find puzzling about the "We want our train!" crowd is why so many of them won't ride the express buses. In most cases they will be faster than the meandering, never-gonna-be-built-in-our-lifetime commuter rail between Denver and Boulder would have been anyway.

Comment: You act as if all wedding cakes are the same, and they are not. Each one is an individually commissioned piece, the result of a contract between "willing" participants to the terms of the contract. Jack Phillips didn't refuse to sell the homosexual couple a cake sitting in his display case. He refused to be hired to create a unique item for them. Contract law is well established, it requires that all parties be voluntary participants to the terms and conditions of the contract. There is not a "universal" contract for wedding cakes. Each one is unique to the tastes and size of the party desiring to hire a baker to bake a cake for them. I would hazard a guess that there are potentially thousands of variables involved; how many layers, are the layers all the same flavor or varying. What size is the lowest layer, middle layers and top layer? 
Do you really want to live in a country where you can be forced to labor for the benefit of another against your will? I sure don't.

Comment: John, I looked you up on LinkedIn and you appear to have a background in research. I think you should therefore agree that A. I think I can agree with you that we don't have adequate data to determine there is not a harm to Kauai / etc. from pesticide use (be it from seed companies, government, or homeowners). Comment: I'm glad to see that this time, PUD isn't going to load this whole increase onto the base charge, as has become normal around here.  

When the electric bill for a tiny house that uses 800 KW a day goes up by the same $5, or $10, as the bill for a large house that uses 2500 KW a day, the small user is getting stuck with a much bigger increase than the big one. 

This increase, by contrast, will be at least a little bit fair.  

And our PUD does a good job of keeping costs down  --  any time I start feeling indignant about my PUD rate increases, I just ask somebody who lives in the City of PA what they pay for their utilities.  I'm always shocked.  Then I contemplate the small, uncomplicated grid that City Light maintains, versus the huge, sprawling, challenging one PUD keeps up  --  and I go back to feeling pretty good about our PUD.

Comment: Look at the survival rate (or if you prefer, the mortality rate) for the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
Look at the survival rate at various distances from ground zero.  Essentially zero fatalities at two miles from ground zero.
Hiroshima stands on a flat river delta, with few hills to shelter the the city.  These factors meant that the death toll and destruction in Hiroshima was particularly high.
In contrast, the center of Nagasaki, the harbor, and the historic district were shielded from the blast by the hills around the Urakami River.

Hiroshima, pre-raid population:  255,000
Dead 	66,000
Injured 	69,000
120,000 (not dead and not injured) 47% 

Nagasaki, pre-raid population: 195,000
Dead 	39,000
Injured 	25,000 
135,000 (not dead and not injured) 69% 

Tsutomu Yamaguchi survived both the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bombings, and lived until he was 93 years old.

Protect yourself from burns, flying glass, and falling debris to survive, unless you are directly under it.

Comment: 1) "Do we have to respect..."
-- By "respect" I mean  that everyone is entitled to their opinions. I am not saying that we have to accept those opinion. Yes, as you said, their right to opinion. Regarding Satan, well, I guess he has the same right, but everyone's choices have consequences. 

2) "Do you respect the opinion of others or the Church?"
-- I do. It doesn't mean I agree with everything. But, again, everyone has the right to their opinions.

3) "To oppose cutting up ..."
-- In my opinion, abortion is not acceptable unless in cases of rape or if the life of the mother is endangered.

4) "To oppose someone who ..."
-- Opposing, disagreeing with, not accepting someone's views and beliefs is certainly a reasonable right. Denigrating them personally for that is "spiritual arrogance." 
For example., do I have the right to reject perfectionism?

Comment: Medical care is provided by the provinces, with a federal payment of roughly 20% of that cost.  Property taxes go to the municipalities only, so you are really mixing up benefits with the levels of governments supplying same and the taxes paying for them.  The low property taxes reflect on poor urban infrastructure - If property taxes were double in Toronto, building more subway lines would not be a problem.  That might drive a lot of seniors out of housing and would just further restrict housing to the well off in Toronto.  Since only the well-off are able to afford housing, maybe not a problem as long as tax system shields seniors from full brunt of the increases.  Remember, provincial and federal governments  tax income (and sales), not assets.  Any money in the bank is generally "after-tax" money in Canada (RRSPs being an exception) and that applies to bank balances transferred in.

Comment: As with so many things Trump says it is difficult to differentiate any real policies he might plan on implementing from the senseless bluster.

The reality, of course, is that Trump doesn't have any authority at all to implement any new tax.  The U.S. Constitution very clearly states that all taxes MUST originate in the House of Representatives.  Now Trump could well find some allies in that House to champion his bills, but he himself certainly can't tax GM or any company.

Further the U.S. government, as a whole, can't unilaterally place an import tax on anything manufactured in Canada or Mexico for arbitrary reasons.  Doing so would be a blatant violation of NAFTA and would be akin to the U.S. unilaterally pulling out of that agreement.

The last time the U.S. did such a thing was 1929 when the Smoot-Hawley Tariff turned the recession of that year into The Great Depression.

Comment: That's not entirely true, the price of NG never really recovered from the 2008 crash, and that was precisely because of fracking and increased exploration which hit the NG sector half a decade before it did, oil. The whole LNG thing was supposed to solve the glut by draining the surplus out of the North American market, allowing the price to rise back to where they though it should be.

Comment: You are right.  We did not use that handle to classify Friedman and Hayek when I was in university.  

Per Wikipedia:

The definition and usage of the term have changed over time.[5] It was originally an economic philosophy that emerged among European liberal scholars in the 1930s in an attempt to trace a so-called "third" or "middle" way between the conflicting philosophies of classical liberalism and socialist planning.

In the 1960s, usage of the term "neoliberal" heavily declined. When the term was reintroduced in the 1980s in connection with Augusto Pinochet's economic reforms in Chile, the usage of the term had shifted. It had not only become a term with negative connotations employed principally by critics of market reform, but it also had shifted in meaning from a moderate form of liberalism to a more radical and laissez-faire capitalist set of ideas.

I graduated with my BA in Poli Sci and Economics in 1977... I missed the shift in the 1980s. Sorry about that.

Comment: Just as there is no free healthcare, free tuition (Bernie Sanders) there is no free parking. Many don't like subsidizing the bus system. Surely they don't like free parking. Some don't like bikes not paying their share. Now that cyclists are going to pay their fair share, why are motorists getting free parking?
On average, cities allocated 7 parking spaces for each car. This is because they design for the maximum possible users, so most of the time the space sits empty.

Yes, they do provide a couple of car spaces for up to 7 bikes. Another benefit to motorists who have fewer motorists to compete with thanks to cyclists.

Comment: No one would argue -- I certainly won't -- that the ACA is perfect. It's really a conservative compromise dating to the Nixon years, an alternative to truly universal healthcare. It can be improved; it should be improved. Obviously, neither Trump nor the Republicans have a plan to do that, or even the desire to do it.  "Repeal and replace" has always meant simply and only "repeal", as we are learning as we watch Trump flailing and floundering, attempting to save the parts of the ACA that people like and want, while having no coherent plan for doing that.  By all means, the ACA needs to be improved; but clearly Trump has no plan to do that.  My point was a very narrow one: that voting for Trump on pro-life grounds was at best naive; it was, for anyone who took the trouble to understand his illiteracy about healthcare policy, a cynical, hypocritical and dishonest rationalization for voting for a uniquely unqualified candidate.

Comment: The concept of waste heat being beneficial is a red herring for a large part.  A 60W bulb generates 3.3 BTU of heat per watt or ~200 BTU total.  The best generators are 25% - 30% efficient so your 60 watt bulb requires 600 BTU worth of diesel fuel to power.  A 60 watt equivalent LED uses 10 watts/33 BTU total so requires ~100 Diesel BTU's to generate.  A decent diesel stove is 80+% efficient making it the heat source of choice.  Moreover, LED's by dint of less demand allow a smaller generating capacity or allow for an entire engine to be shut down if  the efficiencies in a community are scaled.  They also have proportionally less line loss from generator to bulb, aka distribution loss.  We were able to downsize a cabin from a 2kw Honda to a 1kw unit by converting first to CFL's then LED's with the bonus of being able to run an electric coffee pot with a few lights!

Comment: Did you notice that GDP growth is highest in Canada among the G-7 countries? How did we do that when oil prices have crashed in the last 2 years? I suggest that Canada's immigration policy may be the root cause of our relative outperformance. Taking in 0.6% of the net population almost every year since 1988 has left Canada (overall) demographically robust - with the exception of the demographically challenged Atlantic provinces.

Despite a President committed to "growth policies", the USA trail badly. Perhaps, that's because of its anti-immigrant bias which, in aggregate, discourages national consumer spending.

Canada's twin emphasis on selecting the best independent immigrants plus accepting refugees has proven to be worthwhile. 

Still, it is true that even a modestly expanding national population can lead to housing shortages in areas where population growth is robust. Reining in the distorting effects of foreign "hot money" is one action that can offer some modestlylimited relief.

Comment: Back in 2007, at the peak of that fiscal cycle, we had a surplus of about 0.5% of GDP.  By 2009/10, at the worst of the recession/stimulus spending, we had a deficit of 3.5% of GDP.  So from peak to trough we had a swing of 4 percentage points.

Right now, near the peak of the current global economic cycle, we have a deficit of about 1.0% of GDP.  If we were to see a decline in the government's fiscal position by 4 percentage points when the next recession occurs that would mean a deficit of 5.0% of GDP.

That works out to a deficit of approximately $105B.
.

Comment: Much of what is reported in this interesting piece is aided and abetted by...instant communications; it becomes a catch-22: the means of communicating to millions anytime feeds on itself.  Thinking time is short because the ability to deliver a message is there, waiting and--worse--the Pres. is a tweet junkie. So many mistakes or "mispeaking" or "missteps" occur simply because there is little time to reflect, and a decision to "say nothing right now" is rare.  That's the sending end.  On the receiving end, much of the public are now 24/7 news junkies, slavering for updates even when there really aren't any.  Legitimacy is threatened.  Hence, "fake news."

Just a century ago, it was different: no instant mass communication. As most people did NOT live in cities, many never read one of the handful of daily newspapers.  Many were illiterate, most had no telephone.  News travelled more slowly; next week was good enough.  Result: Less "news."  Not today.  Result: chaos reign

Comment: I have long since quit believing the official CPI.  When you consider what has happened to the prices of housing, electricity, food and fuel, and various taxes/fees (e.g. transit), you have to conclude that the rate is manipulated way down.  All the incentives push the government that way: (1) Lower inflation wage increases for the civil service; (2) Lower inflation adjustments for the CPP, OAS, and civil service pensions; (3) "Cover" for ultralow nominal and real rates, making borrowing cheap for overindebted home buyers, as well as all levels of government.  We could instead just cut our bloated governments, primarily via wage reductions that get bigger the more people make.  Then add attrition, and outright layoffs focused on the older staff who have already made $$$ for years, not the eager youngsters.  Throw in a similar pension reform, i.e. "You will only get back what you paid in, not 50% more," and deficits would vanish.  Raise rates, house prices fall, back to normalcy!

Comment: 'And any income from dividends would be taxed at a lower rate than income and would also be subject to tax credits.'

Currently all their investments are in RRSPS and TFSAs. There will be no dividend tax credits on monies withdrawn from those. Money withdrawn from RRSPs is fully taxable as income. Money withdrawn from a TFSA is not taxable at all. 

The dividend tax credit only applies to dividends earned from investments outside a RRSP or TFSA. At this point they have none, although that could change if they downsized their home.

Comment: 3. Decommissioning is needed only in the case of nuclear power.  I hope the author does not mean to imply that solar PV and wind turbines don't need to be decommissioned at the end of their lives.  They do and there are aspects of their decommissioning which require safe disposal facilities.  As to the cost of decommissioning, this is normally covered by including it in the price paid for the electric in the lifetime of the reactor.  With proper regulation the nuclear operator must put aside a fraction of it's income towards eventual decommissioning.  Do the operators of PV and turbines have a similar regulation - or can they simply leave then where they are to rust away?

Google "Decommissioning PV" and "Decommissioning wind turbines" to discover that this is also an aspect of these technologies; decommissioning is NOT only an aspect of nuclear electricity generation.

Comment: Site C is the worst environmental disaster BC has seen in decades. The Peace Athabasca delta was put in great peril during the 4 years it took to fill the Williston reservoir and has yet to recover due to the water level fluctuation. People along the Peace and the delta are staunchly opposed to this dam as are hundreds of scientists, biologists, environmentalists, UNESCO and the United Nations. Organisations such as The Wilderness Committee, Sierra Club, Yellowstone to Yukon, Kairos, Amnesty International and many others have collected a massive amount of signatures to stop the construction of this dam. People from all across the globe have participated in the Write for Rights campaign supporting Indigenous rights and Treaty 8 which is a constitutionally protected treaty, sending over 120,000 cards, letters and drawings to the 2 First Nations fighting this dam. We are at the place in time when we need to protect our water, air & land. Site C destroys all 3 in the Peace River region.

Comment: How about this?

http://www.amren.com/news/2015/07/new-doj-statistics-on-race-and-violent-crime/

This table can be used for a number of interesting calculations. First, we find that during the 2012/2013 period, blacks committed an average of 560,600 violent crimes against whites, whereas whites committed only 99,403 such crimes against blacks. This means blacks were the attackers in 84.9 percent of the violent crimes involving blacks and whites. This figure is consistent with reports from 2008, the last year DOJ released similar statistics. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year Mr. Obama was elected president.

Interestingly, we find that violent interracial crime involving blacks and Hispanics occurs in almost exactly the same proportions as black/white crime: Blacks are the attackers 82.5 percent of the time, while Hispanics are attackers only 17.5 percent of the time.

Comment: Hello, you may be correct that is could be a viable solution. 
I would offer this perspective as a user of public transit for 30 yrs and observer of train, subway rail, light rail, express bus, etc. As a rider I evaluate daily what is optimal for me, and as an engineer I think about how I would improve the system.
To get people out of their cars, transit has to offer cost/time/stress savings. Current transit riders, will  surely take an easier route. People that are on the freeway now, will consider if they improve, (but they are predisposed to drive currently.) The transfer point from one system to another, is a big negative At-grade light rail, with dedicated right-of-way (unshared lane) can offer benefits, but the more the route is mixed with traffic, there is less/no benefit. So a big question is, will an at-grade rail system, with a transfer point, attract current drivers to take transit or will be be mostly for inner urban core. I'm a little skeptical, drivers will want to change
